proposals.reasoning: Diana is the broadly trusted anchor, and including myself matches my earlier stance that Quest 1 should generate information by involving at least one less-certain alignment. This avoids auto-rewarding Alice for self-nominating and doesn’t prematurely cement Charlie as safe, while still forming a team most players indicated they were comfortable with.

votes.comment: No evil on the team, so letting this go through gives a clean result without exposing me or Eve and avoids looking obstructive early.
Diana is a strong anchor and including me gives useful info on Q1 without auto-clearing Alice or Charlie too early.
It’s close for me since I slightly preferred Diana + Charlie, but this still fits the ‘Diana anchor + one info slot’ idea and seems reasonable for Q1.
This was my second-choice team and gives good info early without prematurely clearing Alice or Charlie, and I don’t have a strong reason to distrust Bob yet.
Matches the combo I said I preferred earlier and gives us early info without auto-clearing anyone else.

discussion.content: For the first mission I’d rather keep it simple and low‑risk—something like me and Diana feels reasonable, but I’d be a bit wary of pairing Bob and Eve together this early given how slippery they’ve both been in past games.

I don’t love locking in you and Diana just because it “feels” safe—on Quest 1 I’d rather see at least one player whose alignment we’re unsure about, like me or Charlie, so we actually learn something from the result. If I’m not on it, I’d lean Diana + Charlie over you auto‑including yourself.

I like Bob’s point about getting some info out of Q1—Diana feels like the safest anchor to me, and I’d be most comfortable with either Diana + Charlie or Diana + Bob over auto‑including Alice right away.

I’m fine being the anchor, but I’d slightly prefer Diana + Charlie over Diana + Bob or auto‑including Alice, just so we’re not rewarding Alice for volunteering herself right away while still getting some info. If people hate that, my second choice would be me + Bob.

I’d rather not auto‑reward or auto‑punish anyone for speaking up, so between the options I slightly prefer Diana + Bob for Quest 1—you get a solid anchor plus some real info without quietly cementing Alice or Charlie as “safe” this early.

proposals.reasoning: I’m leaning into the already-successful Bob–Diana pair for early stability and adding myself as the third. This isn’t the most information-maximizing choice, but with good already up 1–0, I’d rather prioritize the highest perceived chance at a second clean mission before we start breaking up the trusted core for more experimental teams.

votes.comment: This doubles down on the same core instead of info-maxing; I’d rather see only one of Bob/Diana plus two new people so we learn more before giving a potential 2–0 lead.
This stacks the prior 2-person pair instead of info-maxing with only one of Bob/Diana; I’d rather see one of us plus two new players for better reads before we lock in a core.
I already argued for doubling down on the clean Bob–Diana pair; with a 1–0 lead I’m fine prioritizing perceived safety over pure info-gain here.
I argued earlier against stacking both of Bob and me again; this is low-info and gives Charlie an easy hide spot if he’s evil. I’d rather see one of Bob/Diana plus two new faces.
It’s too conservative and low‑info; I’d rather see only one of Bob/Diana plus two new players this early instead of doubling down on the same core.

proposals.reasoning: We get exactly one of the clean pair from Mission 1 (me instead of Bob) plus two fresh players, which maximizes new information without fully abandoning the only success data we have. Including myself is safest from my perspective because I know I’m good, and avoiding stacking both Bob and me together again keeps us from overcommitting to a pair that’s only been lightly tested by a 2‑person success. Adding Alice and Charlie lets us see how this wider group behaves and sets up clearer comparisons with any future teams that include Bob or Eve.

votes.comment: I like the info-max structure with only one of Bob/Diana plus two new players, and I want to see how this wider group behaves before we lock in future cores.
Matches the info-max plan of using exactly one from the clean pair plus two new players; no strong reason to distrust this lineup yet and we shouldn’t burn too many early proposals.

I still prefer carrying over Bob from the clean pair rather than swapping him out, and I’m not convinced this mix (me plus two players with no mission record yet) is our safest way to secure a second success right now.
This matches the info-max plan I argued for: exactly one of the initial clean pair plus two new players, and I know I’m good, so I’m fine testing Alice and Charlie here.
Too many untested players together and it fully sidelines both Bob and me after a clean first mission; I’d rather see at least one of Bob/Eve on here for a clearer comparison.

discussion.content: We can’t treat Bob and Diana as auto-clears off a 2‑person success, but it’d be weird to exclude both, so I’d like to see exactly one of them on the next team plus two fresh faces to get more info.

I like the “one of Bob/Diana plus two fresh” idea for info, and obviously I’m going to argue I should be the carry‑over since I know I’m good. Maybe something like me, Alice, and Charlie so we’re not packing all the usual “trusted” faces together too early.

If we want a really solid baseline before we start mixing things up, I’m actually okay doubling down on the clean pair and doing Bob, Diana, and me this round. It’s a bit less “info‑max” than Alice’s idea, but it feels like the safest way to try to lock in a second success early.

I’d rather not just rerun the “trusted core” yet—one of me/Bob plus two new people seems better for info, so something like Bob/Alice/Charlie or me/Alice/Charlie makes more sense to me than stacking both Bob and me together again.

I like rewarding Alice’s info‑max idea, and between Bob/Diana I’m leaning Bob very slightly for now, so a team like Bob, Alice, and me seems like a reasonable balance of carry‑over trust and fresh data.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 1’s only clean info point is Bob on a successful 2-person team, so anchoring on him feels safest. I’m adding myself instead of Diana because she was on both the success and the failed Mission 2 team, which makes her the only common factor across both outcomes and therefore a higher-variance choice right now. A Bob+Eve team keeps Charlie off after the failed Mission 2, avoids repeating the exact same pair that just saw a fail, and gives the table a fresh data point about me while still being grounded in our most trustworthy prior result.

votes.comment: Eve is my teammate, so this lineup gives evil a strong chance to control this pivotal 2-player mission.
I know I’m good, and this keeps all three players from the failed Mission 2 off the team, so the only risk is Eve being evil, which seems acceptable for this swing mission.
I’d rather stick with the fully clean Bob+Diana pair for this crucial swing mission than add an untested player from outside that proven combo.
I trust myself more than untested Eve; I’d rather see the proven Mission 1 pair (Bob + me) than risk a potentially double-evil Bob+Eve team on this swing mission.
Bob is our only fully clean data point from Mission 1, and pairing him with a new player while keeping Charlie off after the fail seems like the safest, most informative option right now.

discussion.content: Given Mission 1 was clean with Bob and Diana, I’m inclined to think the fail on Mission 2 most likely came from either Charlie or (less likely) me being paired with them, so I’d like to see a team that keeps Charlie off for now. Maybe we go back to something centered around Bob and Diana, or swap in Eve for one of them to get a new data point.

I’m happy to go back to the Mission 1 core of me and Diana, since that’s our only clean info so far, but if people are nervous about Diana being on both teams, I’d rather try me with Eve than bring Charlie again right now.

I’m okay treating Mission 1’s clean result as our best anchor for now, so a Bob + Diana team makes the most sense to me here. If we want new info later we can branch out, but for this crucial swing mission I’d rather stick with the only fully proven pair.

Given Mission 1’s clean result, I’m most comfortable with sticking to Bob + me here and treating that as our anchor, which also keeps Charlie (the new variable from the failed Mission 2) off this critical swing mission.

I like anchoring on Bob from the clean Mission 1, but I’m a bit wary of putting Diana on both a success and a fail back-to-back, so I’d rather see something like Bob + me this round to both stay mostly “safe” and get a fresh data point.

proposals.reasoning: Bob and Diana form the only fully clean, overlapping pair from Mission 1’s success, and they weren’t together on either failed mission. The Mission 2 fail must have come from within {Diana, Alice, Charlie}, but since Diana was also part of the clean Mission 1, that points more suspicion toward Charlie. Between Alice and Charlie as the third slot, the table has generally leaned toward trusting Alice more based on reactions after the Mission 2 fail, so anchoring on the proven Bob–Diana pair and adding Alice gives us the team that seems mechanically and socially safest right now.

votes.comment: I’m on the team and with only one fail needed for evil to win, this lineup gives us a straightforward path to ending the game now.

I know I’m good, Eve is highly likely evil from the M3 fail, and exactly one of {Alice, Charlie, Diana} is evil from M2. This team avoids Eve and Charlie (the more suspect from M2), anchors the clean M1 pair (me and Diana), and is the mechanically safest shot at an all-good team.

I still think the safer play is Bob–Diana–me. Mission 2’s fail points somewhere in {Diana, Alice, Charlie}, and if we’re anchoring on the clean M1 pair, I’d rather avoid Alice and keep the team as close as possible to already-proven combinations.

Mechanically the safest: I know I’m good, M1’s Bob–Diana success is our only clean overlap, and between {Alice,Charlie} and {Bob,Eve} we must hit exactly one evil in each pair overall. Socially Charlie+Eve look worse than Alice+Bob right now, so Bob–Diana–Alice is our best bet.
This matches the Bob–Diana core from the clean Mission 1 plus the generally less‑suspected third slot in Alice, which I already said I’d support.

discussion.content: Given the two fail missions, I’m reading the main suspects as Charlie from Mission 2 and Eve from Mission 3, so I’d feel best about a team like Bob–Diana–me where we lean on the clean M1 pairing and avoid that overlap.

I’m happy locking out Eve here since I know I’m clean from M1/M3, and Diana looks best from the M1 success plus the M2 setup. Between Alice and Charlie we know there’s at most one evil, and I’d lean Alice for the third spot but I’m willing to hear arguments either way.

I like locking in Bob–Diana as the core from the clean M1, and between me and Alice for the third slot I’d actually rather we gamble on me and keep the team as close as possible to what’s already worked, so I’d back Bob–Diana–Charlie here.

I’m happiest anchoring around the M1 pair of Bob and me, and from the M2 fail I’m slightly more comfortable adding Alice than Charlie right now. So my preference would be Bob–Diana–Alice for this mission.

Given how clean Bob–Diana look from M1 and the fact that the M2 fail has to come from somewhere in {Diana, Alice, Charlie}, I’m more inclined to trust Alice over Charlie based on how they’ve both reacted since. I’d back a Bob–Diana–Alice team here, but we need to be ready to re‑evaluate hard if this somehow fails.
